case_name: Rabia Bai v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 22 of 1956 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 22 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 4, 1954,

facts.text: Appeal against order dated July 4, 1954 by Custodian-General in Revenue Case No. 427/R Judl./53.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 4, 1954, of the Custodian-General, Evacuee Property, in Revenue Case No. 427/R Judl. /53.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 12, 1961 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal by special leave is directed against the order passed

facts.text: Appellant Rabia Bai is a citizen of India residing at Grange, Yercaud, Salem District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Rabia Bai, who is a citizen of India having her residence at Grange, Yercaud, in the Salem District, came to know in 1949 that premises No. 20, Godown Street,

facts.text: Appellant learned in 1949 that premises No. 20, Godown Street, G.T., Madras was for sale.

anchor.surface_text: came to know in 1949 that premises No. 20, Godown Street, G.T., Madras, was for sale. Since the appellant desired to acquire some immoveable property she arranged

facts.text: Vendor Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad left for Pakistan in 1947 and settled there.

anchor.surface_text: The said premises belonged to one Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad who had left for Pakistan in 1947 and had settled there. The said Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad had executed

facts.text: Vendor executed power of attorney in favour of nephew Ahmed Abdul Gani.

anchor.surface_text: had executed a power of attorney in favour of his nephew, Ahmed Abdul Gani. The said Gani came to Madras in April, 1949, and arranged for the sale,

facts.text: Ahmed Abdul Gani came to Madras in April 1949 and arranged sale.

anchor.surface_text: The said Gani came to Madras in April, 1949, and arranged for the sale, and as a result of negotiations between him and the appellants husband

facts.text: Written agreement for purchase on April 29, 1949 for Rs. 2,40,000.

anchor.surface_text: the latter entered into a written agreement with the former on April 29, 1949, to purchase the said property for Rs. 2,40,000/-. A substantial part of the consideration

facts.text: Rs. 1,50,000 paid immediately in cash and bank drafts on April 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: A substantial part of the consideration to the extent of Rs. 1,50,000 - was paid immediately in the form of cash and bank drafts. Thereafter the sale deed

facts.text: Sale deed stamped on June 27, 1949 at Collector's Office, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: presented at the Collectors Office, Madras, and was duly stamped on June 27, 1949. Income-tax clearance certificate had, however, to be obtained before the said

facts.text: Sale deed registered on August 11, 1949 after income-tax clearance.

anchor.surface_text: the document was presented for registration and was duly registered on August 11, 1949. The balance of the consideration of Rs. 30,000/- was paid before

facts.text: Balance Rs. 30,000 paid before registering officer to M. H. Ganni holding power of attorney.

anchor.surface_text: The balance of the consideration of Rs. 30,000/- was paid before the registering officer to Mr. M. H. Ganni who also held a power of attorney from the vendor.

facts.text: Ordinance No. XII of 1949 extended to Madras on August 23, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Within a fortnight after the registration of the sale deed in favour of the appellant Ordinance No. XII of 1949 which had been promulgated on June 13,1949,

facts.text: Appellant applied for confirmation of sale on December 19, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On December 19, 1949, the appellant applied for confirmation of the sale transaction in her favour. This application was resisted by the tenants who urged

facts.text: Assistant Custodian declared vendor's property evacuee property on January 11, 1951 under s.7(1).

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on January 11, 1951, the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property, Madras City, had declared the property of the vendor to be evacuee property

facts.text: Assistant Custodian rejected confirmation application on July 31, 1951 under s.40(4)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The order refusing to confirm the transaction was passed on July 31, 1951. The appellant challenged the correctness of this conclusion by preferring an appeal

facts.text: Custodian rejected appeal on February 4, 1953 under s.40(4)(a) for lack of good faith.

anchor.surface_text: This order was pronounced on February 4,1953. The appellant then moved the respondent, the Custodian- General in his revisional jurisdiction.

facts.text: Custodian-General dismissed revision on July 4, 1954 under s.40(4)(a).

anchor.surface_text: the revisional application preferred before him by the appellant was dismissed by him on July 4, 1954. In his opinion the appellants case fell under s. 40 4  a

facts.text: Vendor wrote letter to Mohideen on July 4, 1949 expressing fear of new government rules.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reliance was placed on a letter written by the vendor to Mohideen on July 4, 1949. In this letter the vendor had stated that if the matter

facts.text: Court found transaction not in good faith due to vendor's intention to evade evacuee laws.

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, hold that having regard to the aim and object of the emergency legislation with which we are concerned in the present case the expression

facts.text: Valuable consideration was paid, accepted by lower authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian found in favour of the appellant that the sale transaction in question was supported by valuable consideration even so he proceeded to examine

facts.text: Appellant acted in good faith, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: the fact that the appellant paid valuable consideration for the transaction and is not shown to have acted otherwise than in good faith in entering into the transaction

facts.text: Vendor left for Pakistan in June 1947 due to civil disturbances.

anchor.surface_text: the appellate authority considered the fact that the vendor had left for Pakistan in June, 1947, evidently on account of civil disturbances or in fear of such

facts.text: Ordinance No. XII of 1949 promulgated on June 13, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. XII of 1949 which had been promulgated on June 13,1949, was extended to Madras on August 23, 1949.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 4, 1954, of the Custodian-General, Evacuee Property, in Revenue Case No. 427/R Judl. /53.

This appeal by special leave is directed against the order passed by the respondent, the Custodian- General of Evacuee Property, New Delhi, in a revision petition confirming the orders of the subordinate authorities whereby the application made by the appellant for confirmation of the sale transaction in question has been rejected under s. 40  4   a  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, XXXI of 1950.

rejected under s. 40  4   a  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, XXXI of 1950. The appellant, Rabia Bai, who is a citizen of India having her residence at Grange, Yercaud, in the Salem District, came to know in 1949 that premises No. 20, Godown Street, G.T., Madras, was for sale.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 1  of the Ordinance imposed restrictions on transfers by evacuees. In substance this sub-section provided that transfers made by or on behalf of evacuees of any right or interest in their property after such date as may be specified in that behalf with reference to any Province by the Central Government by notification in the official gazette shall not be effective unless they are confirmed by the Custodian.

concepts.unlisted_description: Restrictions on transfers by evacuees and confirmation requirement

anchor.surface_text: Section 38 of this latter Ordinance corresponds to s. 25 of the earlier Ordinance except in one material particular. It provides that no transfer of any right or interest in the property made in any manner whatsoever after the 14th day of August, 1947, by or on behalf of an evacuee as therein specified shall be effective unless it is confirmed by the Custodian.

concepts.unlisted_description: Restrictions on evacuee transfers post 14 Aug 1947

The said provision lays down that a thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly whether it is done negligently or not.

issues.text: whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4 a of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, true that noevacuee law had been extended to Madras at the time when the impugned transaction was completed, and that naturally raises the question as to whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4 a of the Act?

issues.text: whether the expression good faith in s. 40 4 a should be construed in the sense attributed to the said expression by s. 3, sub-s. 22 of the General Clauses Act, X of 1897

anchor.surface_text: the expression good faith in s. 40 4 a should be construed in the sense attributed to the said expression by s. 3, sub-s. 22 of the General Clauses Act, X of 1897. The said provision lays down that a thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly whether it is done negligently or not.

issues.text: whether a transaction affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee can be rejected for confirmation under s. 40 4 a i.e. whether good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that if a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its confirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40 4 a in other words, good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee. In that sense the provisions of s. 40 4 a are more rigorous and stringent than those of s. 53 1 of the Transfer of Property Act.

arguments.claim: Object of Act is to preserve evacuee property for adjustment with Pakistan; retrospective provisions emphasize this; defeating it not good faith

anchor.surface_text: This shows that the main object of the Act was to preserve the property of persons who had migrated to Pakistan till the Government of India could come to some understanding with the Pakistan Government in regard to adjustment of claims of Indian evacuees

holdings.text: It is clear that if a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its confirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40 4 a in other words, good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that if a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its confirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40 4  a  in other words, good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee. In that sense the provisions of s. 40 4  a

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.40(4)(a) requires good faith from both parties; contrasts with TPA s.53(1) which protects bona fide purchaser despite transferor fraud.

holdings.text: The expression 'good faith' in s.40(4)(a) should not be construed per General Clauses Act s.3(22) as there is repugnancy in subject and context.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastris argument is that the expression good faith in s. 40 4  a  should be construed in the sense attributed to the said expression by s. 3, sub-s.  22  of the General Clauses Act, X of 1897. The said provision lays down that a thing shall be deemed

holdings.reasoning_summary: GCA s.3 applies unless repugnant; here repugnant given scope of s.40(1), retrospective effect, and Act's object to preserve evacuee property.

holdings.text: A transaction entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended attracts s.40(4)(a).

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, true that noevacuee law had been extended to Madras at the time when the impugned transaction was completed, and that naturally raises the question as to whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4  a  of the Act?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Considering Act's policy to preserve evacuee property for inter-government adjustment, retrospective provisions, and vendor's letter showing knowledge/intent; absence of extension not decisive.

holdings.text: We would, therefore, hold that having regard to the aim and object of the emergency legislation with which we are concerned in the present case the expression good faith used in s. 40 4  a  has been property construed by the respondent when he held that a deliberate intention to defeat the apprehended application of the evacuee law which was responsible for the transfer in question brings the transfer within the mischief of s. 40 4  a .

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, hold that having regard to the aim and object of the emergency legislation with which we are concerned in the present case the expression good faith used in s. 40 4  a  has been property construed by the respondent when he held that a deliberate intention to defeat the apprehended application of the evacuee law which was responsible for the transfer in question brings the transfer within the mischief of s. 40 4  a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds lower findings on vendor's lack of good faith based on conduct, haste, letter evidencing intent to evade; applies interpreted 'good faith' to facts.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, true that noevacuee law had been extended to Madras at the time when the impugned transaction was completed, and that naturally raises the question as to whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4  a  of the Act?

We would, therefore, hold that having regard to the aim and object of the emergency legislation with which we are concerned in the present case the expression good faith used in s. 40 4 a has been property construed by the respondent when he held that a deliberate intention to defeat the apprehended application of the evacuee law which was responsible for the transfer in question brings the transfer within the mischief of s. 40 4 a .
